DOC.HEAD: With PM-US-China Bjt
Reagan Ambassador to Beijing Condemns Scowcroft Mission
DOC.TEXT: Winston Lord, a career diplomat who served as President Reagan's ambassador to China, today denounced President Bush's decision to send emissaries to Beijing as a ``severely misguided'' step that will make the United States appear weak to China's leaders. ``One does not shore up the long-term foundations for Sino-American relations by appearing weak to China's leaders and callous to the Chinese and American people,'' Lord said in a signed column in today's Washington Post. ``One does not earn respect abroad by reversing field within months and practicing double standards,'' he said. Lord's piece was written before the White House's disclosure on Monday that Brent Scowcroft, Bush's national security adviser, and Lawrence Eagleburger, the deputy secretary of state, secretly visited Beijing on Bush's orders in July. Scowcroft and Eagleburger also visited China earlier this month. The White House announced that visit after they arrived in Beijing. Lord served in Beijing as U.S. ambassador from 1985 to 1989. He was a special assistant to Henry Kissinger when Kissinger first visited China in 1971 and served as a special assistant to the president for national security affairs in the Nixon White House. Bush has come under criticism from Democrats and Republicans alike for the Scowcroft mission, which was undertaken despite the president's pledge to break off high-level contacts until China's leaders acted to repair the damage done in the Tiananmen Square massacre of pro-democracy demonstrators last June. In an interview Monday, Bush said any suggestion that his actions amounted to condoning the repression in China was ``not a good rap, and it's not true.'' Lord said in seeking improved ties with China the administration forfeited the right to censure it on moral grounds. ``But even on its own terms the Scowcroft mission was severely misguided,'' he said, arguing it undermined China's ``closet modererates.'' ``Far from strengthening their hand, the admninistration has robbed them of the argument that Chinese repression and xenophobia entail costs,'' he wrote. ``Japan, Europe and others will feel free to follow the Scowcroft trail.'' The former ambassador said that while censure might not influence China's hard-line leaders, ``international acquiescence'' in the Tiananmen shootings ``surely reinforces their view that crushing their populace elicits only fleeting outcries, no lasting repercussions.'' Lord was especially critical of Scowcroft's toast during the Dec. 8 visit. He said Scowcroft ``lined up the administration with the Beijing regime against the Chinese and American people'' when he said, ``In both our societies there are voices of those who seek to redirect or frustrate our cooperation. We both must take bold measures to overcome these negative forces.'' Lord contrasted those words with what Secretary of State James Baker said two days later in Berlin: ``True stability requires governments with legitimacy, governments that are based on the consent of the governed.''
